top_comment.text: Suddenly the 650s looks good to me, this blue really compliments the car. ﻿
top_comment.author: Rajiv Kishore

comments.text:
I think it would look even better in black. That two tone rear end is the 
only thing that really bothers me about the 650S's styling.
comments.author: fesch198

comments.text:
It took me a while to learn to like the looks of the 650S. Now that i have, 
i think it's beautiful and agressive! This one in blue with these black 
wheels is really pretty and elegant.
comments.author: Groundskeeper Willie

top_comment.text:
Unless you appreciate turbo lag and a weird body style, why would you buy 
this over the 458 or the Huracan?﻿
top_comment.author: João Soares

comments.text: +TheFamousDigital What are they for?
comments.author: João Soares

comments.text:
+João Soares 5. Would you also like to know how many creases there are 
under my left butt cheek?
comments.author: TheFamousDigital

comments.text:
+TheFamousDigital You did? Tell me, how many buttons are there on the 
driver's seat (under your right knee) and what are they for?
comments.author: João Soares

comments.text:
+João Soares I actually recently bought a used 12C, it's not a 650S, but it 
is in my opinion comfortable and spacious, which is only to be enhanced by 
the 650S.
comments.author: TheFamousDigital

comments.text:
+TheFamousDigital If you were ever in a position to buy a 650S you'd 
understand my point,
comments.author: João Soares

comments.text:
+João Soares I want a comfortable supercar with a decent boot space to 
drive every day, because I don't take my car out to the track every week or 
month, let's be honest, I drive it to work and back, to the groceries, to 
dinner. If I want a car to go through the corner, I'd buy a car 
specifically for the track. This isn't one. But anyway, we both have our 
separate tastes.
comments.author: TheFamousDigital

comments.text:
+TheFamousDigital If you want a comfortable car with a big boot space buy a 
Citröen. Supercars are about driving pleasure and in that respect the 650S 
disapoints because of the turbo lag. Nobody wants a supercar you can't 
adjust midcorner with throttle input...
comments.author: João Soares

comments.text:
+João Soares Mainly because the 650S has the most comfortable suspension of 
the three. Biggest boot space. I'd also take it over the Huracan and 458 
because this one has butterfly doors which makes it more special as a 
supercar. So technically, it's more practical, and more special.
comments.author: TheFamousDigital

comments.text:
+M3Conv Way faster? Have proof? The 458 Italia was faster around the 'Ring 
than the 12C. I see no reason why the Speciale wouldn't beat this 650S.
comments.author: Storm Holloway

comments.text:
+João Soares
The 650S is also wayyy faster in a straight line so you don't need to be 
Alonso or Hamilton to enjoy that. The 650S with its revolutionary Tenneco 
Kinetic-based suspension system when on its comfort setting rides like a 
Bentley, the 458 simply cannot do that with its double wishbone stiff setup 
in any mode.
Add that to free power upgrades as they are developed by McLaren and you 
will see why some people are buying them over a 458.
comments.author: M3Conv

comments.text:
+M3Conv It's "wayyy faster" if you're on a track and your surname is Alonso 
or Hamilton. For the average rich man they're exactly the same: too 
powerful. As for being able to serve as a daily driver, it's as comfortable 
as the italian exotica. So, my point still stands.
comments.author: João Soares

comments.text:
because it is wayyy faster i guess, also can be used as daily driver same 
as a 991 series 911, (and also probably wont catch fire)
comments.author: M3Conv

comments.author: kraenk12

top_comment.text:
Good video.. well presented article.
Love the car.. it is a fairy story for most of us and if that Euromillions 
fairy waved her wand at me.. purlease.!!  this would be on my shopping 
list..  
Life is way too short to not enjoy the best if you can. no.?
My only doubt concerns the nose.. to me, it is NOT at all as handsome as 
the 12C.?
Wonder if the factory would paint out that carbon front end thingy.. that 
might make a difference.. or just tack on a 12C nose.?
Just saying.
WF﻿
top_comment.author: William Ferry

comments.text:
Your writer.. faints.!
Fainting..
lol
B
comments.author: William Ferry

comments.text:
I understand your point but I liked the early ish XJ V12s a lot- the XJS 
and XJ6 were appalling, yes. 

I will post a pic of my favoured Jag saloon when I recall where I stored 
the pics!

I am not a fan of modern Jaguar saloons either really. The XK was OK but 
before the F type there was certainly no modern Jag I would choose to own. 
The modern saloons simply look life amorphous blobs to my bleeding eyes!
comments.author: H.T.V. Blu

comments.text:
That's pretty much said it all then.!
For my part, after Jaguar stopped building the Mk2 and S type in the late 
60's they brought out the XJ6 and that lasted until the late 00's.
Despair.!
I despaired of the damn things and the berluddy awful XJS.. dreadful,  the 
pair of them.!!
W. Lyons having carefully built a sporting car company, postwar and thro' 
the 50's, to my delight I might add, then retired and the BMC group 
swallowed it all and trashed it.. all his work.
Things are so much better today, but still, thro' the dark days of the XJ6, 
I and others watched the rise and rise of BMW principally, Audi is a fairly 
recent going-on.. and both were chasing the leading maker of old mens 
motors.. Mercedes.
They were old mens' cars forever.. and with the XJ6 so were Jaguar.!  That 
is precisely where their crap reputation came from.
Young people so do not want Jaguars.. I can see another crashing fall from 
grace..
4 days ago, I took my motor to a local and very special car wash, where the 
wash is done by hand with the greatest care..
There was a young guy, 30's, getting his motor deep cleaned.. an XJ 2.7D.. 
late 08 plate.
My 2 guys had spent 2 days working on it and it sparkled.. was so lovely.. 
you would have to get a Bentley to beat that.
He was 30 ish and clearly weird, but my dear..
I worry about you.!
lol
WF
comments.author: William Ferry

comments.text:
+William Ferry Completely agree though a Porshe 911 is close to fulfilling 
both criteria- mostly through longevity, I guess.

Is it due to Britishness, I wonder, that makes Bentley and Jaguar so 
appealing? They have a particular specialness hard to explain should 
someone be blind to it. Despite the Germans (and in the case of Jaguar 
saloons the Indians too) doing their best to make us forget with their 
tedious offerings.

Although there have been some nice modern Jaguars, for me, none have come 
close to replicating the charm of the older models- and I don't mean only 
the d or e type beauties. I have a hankering for a mark3 V12 saloon with 
pepper pot wheels. It probably has a proper designation but I am afraid I 
do not know it!

I read of a British engineering company (sorry forgotten whom) that is 
specializing in restoring and significantly internally modifying, mainly 
70s Jaguars with, specific concentration on the electrical systems but also 
stripping and rebuilding the mechanicals and refurbishing the interiors. 
One of theirs would be my first car purchase.

The little F type is the first modern Jaguar that has stopped me in my 
tracks though. Very pretty and perfectly balanced design- something so 
frequently lacking in modern car design it seems. I know not why.
comments.author: H.T.V. Blu

comments.text:
Correct answer.. well done that man!
The Britishness.  
I too love Porsche, but Jaguar and Bentley have held my heart since I was a 
schoolboy.  
When the money comes [?] I'm going to have Guy Broad Racing build me an 
XK120FHC, like no other, [ possibly ?] which will be very expensive.  
For half, less than half the cost, I could buy a new full house Cayman S 
which would murder the Jag'.. but why would I.?
The Cayman, tho' delightful, is NOT the dream, is it.. the XK120 tho' time 
and performance has passed it by, remains for me.. the beau ideal.
Sorted then.
WF
comments.author: William Ferry

comments.text:
Good looker and so much more classy than those red Italians. Whether I 
would bother over a 911 is another question- but the 'specialness' and 
British origin may well win me over.
comments.author: H.T.V. Blu

Really wish McLaren would revise their styling. I don't like the look of

comments.text:
I use to have the same opinion as you...until I saw a McLaren in person. 
These McLarens look totally different in person than on video. They are 
stunning! I'm a HUGE Lambo fan, but when I went to the New York Auto Show I 
couldn't keep my eyes off the McLarens....even with Lambos nearby. To be 
honest with you, most of the Lambos looked a little under whelming in 
person when compared to the McLaren's.

captions.text:
McLaren are on a real mission at the moment
and after receiving rave reviews for the P1

hyper car, they've decided to inject some
of its magic into the 12C to create this - the
new 650S.

We've come here to the Ascari race circuit
in Southern Spain and we'll be driving it

at the track, but also out on the Ronda road.
As you can imagine, I'm quite looking forward
to finding out what it's like.

Just weeks after its Geneva Motor Show debut,
the 650S really moves the styling on from

the 12C. That new front end is inspired by
the P1with the same LED lights and carbon

fibre front splitter, new air blades on the
bottom of the doors that funnel air into the

side vents, while at the back, there's an
optional carbon fibre bumper which is meant

to echo McLaren's GT3 car. Lightweight forged
alloys, 19-inches at the front, 20-inches

at the rear an stickier Pirelli P-Zero Corsa
tyres are now standard, as are the frankly

enormous carbon ceramic brake discs. It looks
great too, especially with the striking new
aurora blue paint.

Now, there is quite a good reason that I'm
starting here at the track. McLaren might

say it's not a stripped out special, but let
me talk you through some of the performance

figures the 650S has to offer. The 3.8-litre
twin-turbo engine has got new pistons and

cylinder heads, it's got more boost pressure
for the twin turbos so it now produces 641bhp
and 768nm of torque.

To give you the kind of performance that offers,
it does 0-62mph in just six-seconds flat,

an goes on to 207mph. It also does 0-100mph
in just 5.7 seconds - .7 slower than the P1
which has significantly more power.

So, here we are in the pit-lane, let's go
and find out what it's like.

The 650S is available as both a coupe and
a spyder - that's the drop-top that we tried

around Ascari. The helmets were for our safety,
but that also meant I couldn't hear much in
the cockpit.

It really does feel like 641 brake horse power.
Everything happens so fast that you've just

got to try and keep up with it. The shift
times for the gearbox, the seven-speed auto(matic),

have been improved even further and there's
a cylinder cut system to make the exhaust
sound even louder in sport or track mode.

I'm in track mode at the moment for the powertrain
and the gearbox, and it's the most extreme

mode there is. You really can feel how nailed
down the car is to the road - it's so stable

at high speeds. Even when you're going through
these tight corners, you just can't feel it

move around at all despite all that performance.
It's really impressive.

Starting at the track was definitely the way
to feel all those chassis changes at work,
but what's the 650S like on the road?

As we've already seen at Ascari, the 650S
has some serious firepower. The performance

figures are intimidating. McLaren also say
that here, driving on the road, it's even

more comfortable than a 12C. The engineers
last night told me they did a lot of work

over 12-months working on the damping and
they fitted new dampers which Chris Goodwin

told me are similar to the ones fitted to
the P1 project. They allow for a stiffer side-wall

of tyre to be fitted and stiffer front and
rear springs without any loss in ride-comfort.

The 650S is very refined for a car of this
type and to increase the level of creature

comfort on the inside - although the cabin
is very similar to the 12C - every 650S comes

with an Alcantara steering wheel, and Alcantara
here on the dash and the roof lining.

The car we're driving has some optional leather
trim, but I've seen one of the ones with Alcantara

and it looks fantastic. There is also the
option of some bucket racing seats that are

completely made of carbon. They save about
15 kilos in weight, they're very similar to

the seats in the P1 and are really, really
cracking - a must have option in my opinion.

But forgetting all that, what's the 650S like
on the road? Well, the difference in performance

between this and a 12C is less pronounced
here on the road - you can't quite feel the

extra power and that's mainly because it's
so fast, the moments that you actually have

a spare road in front of you where you can
actually release full-throttle, but make no

mistake, the 650S is a seriously quick car.
The 12C Spyder was probably one of the quickest

cars I've ever driven on the road, and the
650S retains that same almighty acceleration.

As soon as you hear that turbo induction woosh
and suck up above about 3-and-a-half thousand
RPM, it just disappears up the road.

It feels like the 650S has everything turned
up ever so slightly, so there's more grip,

more noise, more power and more pace. The
brakes are better than before and offer far

more natural feel. The steering is superb,
but the car rarely feels playful - it's much

more 
of a serious driving tool.
